'''''Phaeolepiota''''' is a [[genus]] of [[fungi]] in the family [[Agaricaceae]]. This is a [[monotypic]] genus, containing the single species '''''[[Golden bootleg|Phaeolepiota aurea]]'''''. ''P. aurea'', commonly known as '''golden bootleg''' or '''golden cap''' is a [[mushroom]] found throughout [[North America]] and [[Eurasia]] – often next to [[Urtica|nettles]].<ref>{{cite book | author = Phillips R | year = 2005 | title = Mushrooms and Other Fungi of North America | publisher = Firefly Books|page=320 | isbn = 978-1-55407-115-9}}</ref>

==Edibility==
Various cook books recommend the golden bootleg for its fine taste. Later studies have shown that the [[fruit body]] contains unacceptable amounts of both cadmium and cyanide compounds. Therefore, the mushroom is no longer considered edible. Cooking reduces the concentration of the cyanide compounds preset, which might be the reason ''Phaeolepiota aurea'' was considered edible in the past.<ref>[http://www.mushroomthejournal.com/bestof/Paureatext.html Phaeolepiota aurea at mushroomthejournal.com] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080828005706/http://www.mushroomthejournal.com/bestof/Paureatext.html |date=2008-08-28 }}</ref>
